Edit 6 (2025-12-19T18:59:24.167Z):
```great_tables_star_example.py
@@ -0,0 +1,51 @@
+import pandas as pd
+import great_tables as gt
+from star_rating import create_star_rating
+
+def main():
+    """
+    Example of using star ratings in a great-tables table.
+    """
+    # Sample data: Movies with ratings
+    data = {
+        'movie': ['The Shawshank Redemption', 'The Godfather', 'The Dark Knight',
+        'Pulp Fiction', 'Fight Club', 'Inception', 'Interstellar'],
+        'year': [1994, 1972, 2008, 1994, 1999, 2010, 2014],
+        'rating': [4.9, 4.8, 4.5, 4.3, 4.0, 4.4, 4.6]
+    }
+    restaurant_data = pd.DataFrame(data)
+
+    # Create a great-tables table
+    table = (
+        gt.GT(restaurant_data)
+        .tab_header(title="Top Movies")
+        .fmt_number(
+            columns=["rating"],
+            decimals=1
+        )
+        .cols_label(
+            movie="Movie Title",
+            year="Year",
+            rating="Rating (out of 5)"
+        )
+        # Apply star rating to the 'rating' column
+        .fmt_html(
+            columns=["rating"],
+            fn=lambda x: create_star_rating(x)
+        )
+        # Add styling
+        .tab_style(
+            style=gt.css(font_weight="bold"),
+            locations=gt.cells_column_labels()
+        )
+    )
+
+    # Save to HTML file
+    table.render_html("movie_ratings_table.html")
+    print("Table created: movie_ratings_table.html")
+
+    # Return the table object for display in notebook environments
+    return table
+
+if __name__ == "__main__":
+    main()
\ No newline at end of file
```
